repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This PR caps the time tree-sitter can take to parse a file to match
`'redrawtime'`, and raises an error if it takes too long.

TODO:
- [x] Basic implementation
- [ ] If a timeout occurs, disable the highlighting for this redraw cycle, and resume parsing in the next one

cc @clason

comment_data.body: Do we really want to reset the parser unconditionally? IIRC this is only necessary if there is an edit after an incomplete parse was aborted. otherwise, next time parsing the buffer is attempted, we should just let it continue on the existing job (still having the same deadline of course).
Hmm maybe that's better indeed... I'll try to handle that then.

Shouldn't the time be tracked on the Lua side. Redraw consists of multiple parsing and questing attempts (injections). When the first parsing attempt finishes the time needed should be subtracted from the deadline of the remaining tasks so that the total time budget doesn't get overly exceeded. But this PR would of course be good enough enough for a first iteration.
to add, subsequent parses will be quicker than the initial, but if the initial always timeouts, then it'll never finish a full parse.

comment_regular_data.body: bump -- last big treesitter PR for 0.8?

Not sure I'll be able to make that land for 0.8, but we can try.
I push that up in my todo list.
Not a blocker, just nice to have. We can push to 0.9 if there are more urgent things.
@vigoux I hope you are well. please complete this, I'm working on some big python files and neovim completely hangs for few minutes :(
@sabah1994 This is not how this works. If you really need it, you should work on this yourself. In the meantime, just disable nvim-treesitter for Python files.

> Different approach in #22420

They are complementary, no? I.e. worth having both.
